GIT

Git Configuration

Statement

  • cat .gitconfig
  • git config –global –list
  • cat ~/.gitconfig
  • git config –global core.editor sublime
  • git config –global help.autocorrect 1
  • git config –global colour.ui auto
  • git config –global core.autocrlf input
  • git config –global –list
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ cat .gitconfig
[user]
	name = Chaudhry Usman Ali
	email = maniali@gmail.com
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ cat ~/.gitconfig
[user]
	name = Chaudhry Usman Ali
	email = maniali@gmail.com
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ git config --global --list
user.name=Chaudhry Usman Ali
user.email=maniali@gmail.com
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ cat ~/.gitconfig
[user]
	name = Chaudhry Usman Ali
	email = maniali@gmail.com
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ git config --global core.editor sublime
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ git config --global help.autocorrect 1
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ cd Downloads
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads$ cd gitplay
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git statsu
WARNING: You called a Git command named 'statsu', which does not exist.
Continuing under the assumption that you meant 'status'
in 0.1 seconds automatically...
fatal: Not a git repository (or any of the parent directories): .git
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ cd
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ gitconfig colour.ui auto
gitconfig: command not found
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ git config --global colour.ui auto
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ git config --global core.autocrlf input
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ git config --global --list
user.name=Chaudhry Usman Ali
user.email=maniali@gmail.com
core.editor=sublime
core.autocrlf=input
help.autocorrect=1
colour.ui=auto
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ cat ~/.gitconfig
[user]
	name = Chaudhry Usman Ali
	email = maniali@gmail.com
[core]
	editor = sublime
	autocrlf = input
[help]
	autocorrect = 1
[colour]
	ui = auto

Creating a local Repo, adding files and committing changes

Statements

  • git init
  • git status
  • git add
  • git commit -m “Added readme”
mani@mani-ubu12x:~$ cd Downloads
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads$ cd gitplay
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ dir

Viewing History and Diffs

Statements

  • git diff 957304..ec750d
  • git diff HEAD~1..HEAD
  • git diff HEAD~1..
  • git add -u
  • git add -A
*************************************************************
# Compare using Hash
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git diff 957304..ec750d
diff --git a/README.txt b/README.txt
index b7aec52..a10a8a5 100644
--- a/README.txt
+++ b/README.txt
@@ -1 +1,2 @@
 Hello, Git
+Hello
\ No newline at end of file
***************************************************************
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git diff HEAD~1..HEAD
diff --git a/README.txt b/README.txt
index b7aec52..a10a8a5 100644
--- a/README.txt
+++ b/README.txt
@@ -1 +1,2 @@
 Hello, Git
+Hello
\ No newline at end of file
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git diff HEAD~1..
diff --git a/README.txt b/README.txt
index b7aec52..a10a8a5 100644
--- a/README.txt
+++ b/README.txt
@@ -1 +1,2 @@
 Hello, Git
+Hello
\ No newline at end of file
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ touch file1.txt file2.txt
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Untracked files:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
#
#	file1.txt
#	file2.txt
nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git add -u
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Untracked files:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
#
#	file1.txt
#	file2.txt
nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
******************************************************************************
-A option (track untracked whatever is in there add it all)

# Changes to be committed:
#   (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)

Staging Changes as multiple commits

Statement

  • git add file1.txt
  • git commit -m “Fixed bug 1234”
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ sudo sublime file1.txt
[sudo] password for mani: 
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ sudo sublime README.txt
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
#	modified:   README.txt
#	modified:   file1.txt
#
no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ echo "I want to stage these as two different commits"
I want to stage these as two different commits
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git add file1.txt
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Changes to be committed:
#   (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)
#
#	modified:   file1.txt
#
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
#	modified:   README.txt
#
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ echo "file1 is staged but README not staged"
file1 is staged but README not staged
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git commit -m "Fixed bug 1234"
[master 272b13a] Fixed bug 1234
 1 file changed, 1 insertion(+)
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git add README.txt
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git commit -m "Fixed typo in README.txt and added additional information about other features"
[master f58350e] Fixed typo in README.txt and added additional information about other features
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)

  • rm file2.txt
  • git add -A
Remove a file or Delete
 rm file2.txt

file1.txt  file3.txt  imagefield_prev_gen  README.txt

# Changes to be committed:
#   (use "git reset HEAD <file>..." to unstage)

#   (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)

#	file3.txt

Undoing changes to the working copy

Statements

  • git checkout README.txt
  • git status
  • git reset –hard
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ sudo sublime README.txt
[sudo] password for mani: 
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
#	modified:   README.txt
#
no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ echo "Well I just realized I didn`t want to do what I just did"
> 
> ^C
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git checkout README.txt
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
nothing to commit (working directory clean)
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ cat README.txt
Hello, Git
Hello
Updating README with new informationmani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ 
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ sublime README.txt 
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ echo "to revert changes - checkout"
to revert changes - checkout
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ sudo sublime README.txt
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ rm new_file.txt 
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add/rm <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
#	modified:   README.txt
#	deleted:    new_file.txt
#
no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ echo "I can stage these changes one at a time"
I can stage these changes one at a time

*************************************************************************************

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ echo "I can do a hard reset"
I can do a hard reset
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git reset --hard
HEAD is now at ec7b206 Reorganized the feature
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
nothing to commit (working directory clean)
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ echo "I have removed all the changes"
I have removed all the changes

Undoing and redoing changes

Statement

  • git reset –hard
  • git reset –hard HEAD~1
  • git status
  • git reset –soft HEAD~1
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git reset --hard
HEAD is now at ec7b206 Reorganized the feature
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ echo "so last commit has been taken out of the repository"
so last commit has been taken out of the repository
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git reset --hard HEAD~1
HEAD is now at f58350e Fixed typo in README.txt and added additional information about other features
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
nothing to commit (working directory clean)

Reset Notes

git reset --hard HEAD~1

Delete last commit. Move head back. Discard all changes. 

git reset --soft HEAD~1

I can make changes in the last commit. Make fixes and re-commit.

Difference between soft and hard reset

When you modify a file in your repository, the change is initially unstaged. In order to commit it, you must stage it—that is, add it to the index—using git add. When you make a commit, the changes that are committed are those that have been added to the index.

git reset changes, at minimum, where your current branch is pointing. The difference between –mixed and –soft is whether or not your index is also modified. So, if we're on branch master with this series of commits:

- A - B - C (master) HEADpoints to C and the index matches C.

When we run git reset –soft B, master (and thus HEAD) now points to B, but the index still has the changes from C; git status will show them as staged. So if we run git commit at this point, we'll get a new commit with the same changes as C.

Okay, so starting from here again:

- A - B - C (master) Now let's do git reset –mixed B. Once again, master and HEAD point to B, but this time the index is also modified to match B. If we run git commit at this point, nothing will happen since the index matches HEAD. We still have the changes in the working directory, but since they're not in the index, git status shows them as unstaged. To commit them, you would git add and then commit as usual.

And finally, –hard is the same as –mixed (it changes your HEAD and index), except that –hard also modifies your working directory. If we're at C and run git reset –hard B, then the changes added in C, as well as any uncommitted changes you have, will be removed, and the files in your working copy will match commit B. Since you can permanently lose changes this way, you should always run git status before doing a hard reset to make sure your working directory is clean or that you're okay with losing your uncommitted changes.

Clean working copy

Statements

  • git clean -n (What to remove)
  • git clean -f (Remove)
  • git status
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads$ cd gitplay
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ ls -la
total 28
drwxrwxr-x  5 mani mani 4096 Mar 18 13:25 .
drwxr-xr-x 16 mani mani 4096 Mar 18 16:05 ..
-rw-rw-r--  1 mani mani   21 Mar 18 13:25 file1.txt
-rw-rw-r--  1 mani mani    0 Mar 18 13:25 file2.txt
drwxrwxr-x  8 mani mani 4096 Mar 18 13:25 .git
drwxrwxr-x  2 mani mani 4096 Mar 15 11:45 imagefield_prev_gen
-rw-rw-r--  1 mani mani   53 Mar 18 12:13 README.txt
drwxrwxr-x  2 mani mani 4096 Mar 18 13:24 status
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ touch temp1.txt temp2.txt
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Untracked files:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
#
#	temp1.txt
#	temp2.txt
nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git clean -n
Would not remove status/
Would remove temp1.txt
Would remove temp2.txt
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git clean -f
Not removing status/
Removing temp1.txt
Removing temp2.txt
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
nothing to commit (working directory clean)

Git Ignore

Statements

  • git status
  • sudo sublime .gitignore
  • git status
  • git add .gitignore
  • git commit -m “Added gitignore”
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads$ cd gitplay
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ dir
file1.txt  file2.txt  imagefield_prev_gen  README.txt  status
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ mkdir logs
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ touch logs/log.txt
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Untracked files:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
#
#	logs/
nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ sudo sublime .gitignore
[sudo] password for mani: 

*****************************************************************************
/logs/*.txt
/logs/*.log
/logs
*****************************************************************************

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Untracked files:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
#
#	.gitignore
nothing added to commit but untracked files present (use "git add" to track)
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git add .gitignore
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git commit -m "Added gitignore"
[master 77676e2] Added gitignore
 1 file changed, 3 insertions(+)
 create mode 100644 .gitignore
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
nothing to commit (working directory clean)
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git log
commit 77676e28270b92e8a29fa493e7077524ffbc293d
Author: Chaudhry Usman Ali <maniali@gmail.com>
Date:   Mon Mar 18 16:43:49 2013 -0300

    Added gitignore

Git Protocols

HTTPS

http(s) uses port 80/443 
https://github.com/jquery/jquery.git
(Read-write, password for authorization, Firewall friendly)

GIT

git uses port __9418__
git://github.com/jquery/jquery.git
(Read-only, Anonymous only, not firewall friendly)


SSH

ssh uses port __22__
git@github.com:jquery/jquery.git
(Read-write, SSH keys for authorization)

cat .git/config

Core 

repositoryformatversion = 0
filemode = true
bare = false
logallrefupdates = true

Remote “origin” 

fetch = +refs/heads/*:refs/remotes/origin/*
url = https://github.com/jquery/jquery.git

Branch “master” 

remote = origin
merge = refs/heads/master

git log origin/master
git merge origin/master (merge remote master with my local master)

Already up-to-date.

Simple Git Fast Forward

Move head pointer to the new location 

Your branch is behind 'origin/master' by 1 commit, and can be fast-forwarded
git pull
git pull origin master

You’ll notice the phrase “Fast forward” in that merge. Because the commit pointed to by the branch you merged in was directly upstream of the commit you’re on, Git moves the pointer forward. To phrase that another way, when you try to merge one commit with a commit that can be reached by following the first commit’s history, Git simplifies things by moving the pointer forward because there is no divergent work to merge together — this is called a “fast forward”.

Pulling from Remote

Statements

git branch -r (Show remote branch)

Git Pull 

git fetch; git merge origin/master;

So what is Pull?

  1. Fetch while checking differences and updates
  2. Merge the remote master with my local master
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git branch -r
  origin/master

If we haven`t set up a correspondence between my master branch and the origin(remote) master branch then git will be confused. Git will not know what to do. So, we have to set up an upstream tracking branch.

Upstream Tracking Branch

What branch remotely does my local branch mirror? 

*********Establish correspondence ***************

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git branch --set-upstream master origin/master
Branch master set up to track remote branch master from origin.

Pull any new changes down

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git pull
Already up-to-date.

If we want to avoid establishing upstream 

git pull origin master (Specify remote name and branch that I want to pull in)

Differences between git pull origin master and git pull origin/master

git pull origin master will pull changes from the origin remote, master branch and merge them to the local checked-out branch.

git pull origin/master will pull changes from the locally stored branch origin/master and merge that to the local checked-out branch. The origin/master branch is essentially a “cached copy” of what was last pulled from origin, which is why it's called a remote branch in git parlance. This might be somewhat confusing.

You can see what branches are available with git branch and git branch -r to see the “remote branches”.

Pushing to a Remote

git commit -am “Sharing is easy” - Add and commit at the same time. 

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ sudo sublime README.txt 
[sudo] password for mani: 
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
#	modified:   README.txt
#
no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")


ADD and COMMIT
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git commit -am "Sharing is easy"
[master efdad19] Sharing is easy
 1 file changed, 2 insertions(+), 1 deletion(-)
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch master
# Your branch is ahead of 'origin/master' by 1 commit.
#
nothing to commit (working directory clean)

PUSH

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git push 
Username for 'https://github.com': vermuz
Password for 'https://vermuz@github.com': 
Counting objects: 5, done.
Delta compression using up to 2 threads.
Compressing objects: 100% (3/3), done.
Writing objects: 100% (3/3), 349 bytes, done.
Total 3 (delta 1), reused 0 (delta 0)
To https://github.com/vermuz/pdfimagefieldcapture.git
   77676e2..efdad19  master -> master

SICK OF PUSHING PASSWORDS?

  1. git remote rm origin (Remove remote origin)
  2. git remote -v (Check Remotes)
  3. git remote add origin git@github.com:vermuz/pdfimagefieldcapture.git (Add SSH connection)
  4. git push (Push)
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git remote rm origin
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git remote -v
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git remote add origin git@github.com:vermuz/pdfimagefieldcapture.git
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git push
Everything up-to-date

Creating and Verifying Tags

Statements

  • git tag (show tags)
  • git tag -l 'v1.4.2.*' (Search tags)
  • git tag -a v1.4 -m 'my version 1.4' (Create an annotated tag)
  • git tag -s v1.5 -m 'my signed 1.5 tag' (Signed tag)
  • git tag -v v1.4.2.1 (verify tag)

Pushing Tags to a Remote

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git push --tags
Counting objects: 1, done.
Writing objects: 100% (1/1), 180 bytes, done.
Total 1 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
To git@github.com:vermuz/pdfimagefieldcapture.git
 * [new tag]         v1.0 -> v1.0
 * [new tag]         v1.0_with_message -> v1.0_with_message

Difference between branches and tags

Branch (will follow commits, new commits will result in branches moving along)
Tags (will stay with the commit where they were created) alias for the SHA1 commit

Stashing Changes

Often, when you’ve been working on part of your project, things are in a messy state and you want to switch branches for a bit to work on something else. The problem is, you don’t want to do a commit of half-done work just so you can get back to this point later. The answer to this issue is the git stash command.

Stashing takes the dirty state of your working directory — that is, your modified tracked files and staged changes — and saves it on a stack of unfinished changes that you can reapply at any time. 

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git checkout feature2
Switched to branch 'feature2'

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ echo "Feature2 changes" >> README.txt

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git status
# On branch feature2
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
#	modified:   README.txt
#
# Untracked files:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
#
#	Added feature2
no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")

These changes are not ready to be checked into feature2. I don`t want to lose them.

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git stash 
Saved working directory and index state WIP on feature2: cdc130d Added feature2
HEAD is now at cdc130d Added feature2

Pending changes to the working copy have been rolled back.

ReadMe file does not contain the change, echo “Feature2 changes” 

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ cat README.txt
Hello, Git
Hello
Updating README with new information
Sharing remotely is fun and easyFeature2

Those changes are in my git stash, a holding area for pending changes 

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git stash list
stash@{0}: WIP on feature2: cdc130d Added feature2

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git checkout bug1234
Switched to branch 'bug1234'

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ echo "Another fix to bug1234" >> README.txt

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git commit -am "Really fixing bug1234"
[bug1234 f2e8d5a] Really fixing bug1234
 1 file changed, 1 insertion(+)

Checkout feature2 and pull changes back 

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git checkout feature2
Switched to branch 'feature2'

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git stash apply
# On branch feature2
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
#	modified:   README.txt
#
# Untracked files:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
#
#	Added feature2
no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ cat README.txt
Hello, Git
Hello
Updating README with new information
Sharing remotely is fun and easyFeature2
Feature2 changes

You see your changes reapplied.

Git stash list, 

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git stash list
stash@{0}: WIP on feature2: cdc130d Added feature2

To toss out changes 

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git reset --hard HEAD
HEAD is now at cdc130d Added feature2

We don`t have Feature2 changes now, 

HEAD is now at cdc130d Added feature2
mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ cat README.txt
Hello, Git
Hello
Updating README with new information
Sharing remotely is fun and easyFeature2

Pop an item from the stash and apply it to current working copy, yep use pop 

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git stash pop
# On branch feature2
# Changes not staged for commit:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to update what will be committed)
#   (use "git checkout -- <file>..." to discard changes in working directory)
#
#	modified:   README.txt
#
# Untracked files:
#   (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
#
#	Added feature2
no changes added to commit (use "git add" and/or "git commit -a")
Dropped refs/stash@{0} (918816032acef183f4dd9e18e56abf2b740cc86b)

However, the above action despite applying the change from the stash list will remove it from the stash list. 

mani@mani-ubu12x:~/Downloads/gitplay$ git stash list

Remotes

  • Ability to collaborate with others.
  • Local changes.
  • Pushed to remote server so others can see them.
  • People can download those changes on their machines.
  • We can download changes made by them on our machines.
